'''Viktor Anatolyevich Bout''' ({{IPAc-en|b|uː|t}}; {{lang-ru|link=no|Ви́ктор Анато́льевич Бут}}; born 13 January 1967) is a [[Russia]]n [[arms dealer]].
Bout, an [[entrepreneur]] and former [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] military translator, reportedly used his multiple [[air transport]] companies to smuggle weapons since the [[Revolutions of 1989|collapse of communism]] from [[Eastern Europe]] to [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]] during the 1990s and early 2000s.<ref name="Economist" /><ref name="Bout FAQ">[http://www.victorbout.com/FAQ.htm Victor Bout's Personal Website, FAQ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607041502/http://www.victorbout.com/FAQ.htm |date=7 June 2009 }}. Victorbout.com.</ref><ref name="LentapedBout">[http://www.lenta.ru/lib/14187802/ Бут, Виктор]</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/07/thailand.russia "'Lord of war' arms trafficker arrested"], ''The Guardian'', 7 March 2008.</ref> Bout was nicknamed the ''Merchant of Death'' and ''Sanctions Buster'' for his reported wide-reaching operations, extensive clientele, and willingness to bypass [[embargo]]es.<ref name="Economist"/><ref name="Observer"/><ref name="BBC Profile">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7281885.stm "Viktor Bout"]. BBC Profile.</ref>
On March 6, 2008, Bout was arrested in [[Thailand]] on [[terrorism]] charges by the [[Royal Thai Police]] in cooperation with American authorities, and the United States ambassador requested his [[extradition]] under the Extradition Act with Thailand, which was eventually mandated by the Thai High Court in August 2010.<ref name="Observer"/><ref name="Interpol1"/><ref name="extradition">[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/2010/09/01/opinion/Appeal-Court-verdict-on-the-extradition-of-Bout-30136994.html "Appeal Court verdict on the extradition of Bout"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918055728/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/2010/09/01/opinion/Appeal-Court-verdict-on-the-extradition-of-Bout-30136994.html |date=18 September 2010 }}. ''The Nation'', 1 September 2010.</ref> Bout was accused of [[Intention (criminal law)|intending]] to smuggle arms to the [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia]] (FARC) for use against U.S. forces in [[Colombia]], but denied his charges and predicted an [[acquittal]].<ref name="extradition" /><ref name="justice.gov">[http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2010/November/10-ag-1306.html Viktor Bout Extradited to the United States to Stand Trial on Terrorism Charges] [[United States Department of Justice]] release, 17 November 2010.</ref><ref name="lead1" /><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/21/world/asia/21thai.html "Arms Suspect Vows to Win Case in U.S. After Extradition Order"], nytimes.com, 21 August 2010.</ref><ref>[http://newsru.com/russia/20aug2010/domoi.html Россия хочет заполучить "оружейного барона" Бута, которого отправляют на суд в США] [[NEWSru]], 20 August 2010.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11036569 Profile: Viktor Bout] BBC News, 2 November 2011</ref> On 2 November 2011, Bout was convicted by a jury in a [[Manhattan]] federal court of [[Conspiracy (criminal)|conspiracy to kill]] U.S. citizens and officials, delivery of [[anti-aircraft missiles]], and providing aid to a terrorist organization, and was sentenced to 25 years' [[imprisonment]].<ref name="AP-11-2-2011">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/02/viktour-bout-convicted-arms-deal |title=Russian Viktor Bout convicted over Colombian arms deal |agency=The Associated Press |date=2 November 2011 |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-15565305 "Viktor Bout guilty of Colombian rebel arms deal"]. BBC, 2 November 2011.</ref> Since June 2012, Bout has been held at the [[United States Penitentiary, Marion]].<ref name="BOP">{{cite web|url=http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=IDSearch&needingMoreList=false&IDType=IRN&IDNumber=91641-054&x=88&y=11|title=Inmate Locator|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Prisons]]|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="BBC News">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-17634050 "'Merchant of Death' Viktor Bout sentenced to 25 years"].</ref><ref>[http://www.justice.gov/usao/nys/pressreleases/April12/boutviktorsentencingpr.pdf "International Arms Dealer Viktor Bout Sentenced in Manhattan Federal Court to 25 Years in Prison for Terrorism Crimes"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413063146/http://www.justice.gov/usao/nys/pressreleases/April12/boutviktorsentencingpr.pdf |date=13 April 2012 }}, Press Release, United States Attorney, Southern District of New York, 5 April 2012.</ref><ref>[http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_06_20/78663701/ "Victor Bout delivered to Marion Prison"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705101427/http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_06_20/78663701/ |date=5 July 2012 }}, The Voice of Russia, 20 June 2012</ref>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Viktor Bout's origins are unclear, except [[United Nations]] documents and Bout himself both state his birthplace as [[Dushanbe]], [[Tajik SSR]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]] (now the capital of [[Tajikistan]]), and that his date of birth is most likely on 13 January, 1967, although several other dates are possible.<ref name="NYT">[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/17/magazine/17BOUT.html?ei=5070&en=64107baa91d5594e&ex=1237521600&pagewanted=all&position= Arms and the Man] New York Times, 17 August 2003</ref><ref name="Four">[http://blogs.channel4.com/snowblog/2009/03/16/meeting-viktor-bout-the-merchant-of-death/ "Meeting Viktor Bout, the ‘Merchant of Death’"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523060748/http://blogs.channel4.com/snowblog/2009/03/16/meeting-viktor-bout-the-merchant-of-death/ |date=23 May 2009 }}, BBC Channel 4 Snowblog, 16 March 2009</ref><ref name="Bout"/><ref name="UNad">[https://www.un.org/Docs/sc/committees/Angola/363e.pdf Addendum to the final report of the Monitoring Mechanism on Sanctions against UNITA] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805204634/http://www.un.org/Docs/sc/committees/Angola/363e.pdf |date=5 August 2009 }} S/2001/363</ref><ref name=de1>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,721532-2,00.html Trapping the Lord of War, The Rise and Fall of Viktor Bout] Part 2: Secretive about His Past. spiegel.de, 6 October 2010</ref><ref name="ethz"/> A [[South Africa]]n intelligence file from 2001 listed Bout as being [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] in origin.<ref>[https://foreignpolicy.com/story/cms.php?story_id=3600 "The Merchant of Death"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227021827/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/story/cms.php?story_id=3600 |date=27 December 2008 }}. ''Foreign Policy''.</ref><ref name="merchant">[http://www.douglasfarah.com/pdfs/bout.pdf Douglas Farah and Stephen Braun: "The Merchant of Death"]. (PDF).</ref>
===Military career=== Bout served in the [[Soviet Armed Forces]], but there is no definite information on his military career except that he graduated from the Military Institute of Foreign Languages.<ref name="UNad"/><ref name="christsci"/><ref name=de/> Bout is a [[Polyglotism|polyglot]] believed to be fluent in six languages: [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Arabic]], [[Persian language|Persian]] and [[Esperanto]], which he had mastered by age 12 and in the early 1980s was member of the Dushanbe [[Esperanto club]].<ref name="Economist1">[http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=10853742 Viktor Bout arrested] ''The Economist'', 13 March 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/monde/viktor-bout-seigneur-de-guerres_756307.html?p=2 "Viktor Bout, seigneur de guerres"], ''L'Express'', 24 April 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.agoravox.fr/tribune-libre/article/un-trafiquant-d-arme-polyglotte-55726 "Un trafiquant d’arme, polyglotte émérite, était espérantophone dans sa jeunesse!"] AgoraVox, 12 May 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.liberafolio.org/2009/butesperanto "Komercisto de la morto" estas esperantisto] ''Libera Folio'', 5 May 2009</ref> Bout's personal [[website]] stated that he served in the [[Soviet Army]] as a [[translator]], holding the rank of [[lieutenant]].<ref name="Bout FAQ"/> He is thought to have been discharged from the Soviet Army in 1991 with the rank of [[lieutenant colonel]] to start an [[air freight]] business, but other sources state he was a [[major]] in the [[GRU]], an [[military officer|officer]] in the [[Soviet Air Forces]], that he graduated from a Soviet [[military intelligence]] training program, or an operative of the [[KGB]].<ref name="Economist"/><ref name="Observer"/><ref name="NYT"/><ref name=de1/> Bout was involved with a Soviet military operation in [[Angola]] in the late 1980s assisting the [[MPLA]] in the [[Angolan Civil War]], stating that he was only in Angola for a few weeks.<ref name="NYT"/><ref name="UNad"/><ref name="christsci"/><ref name=merchant-death-book />
==Operations== ===1990s=== According to Bout's personal website, he began his first air freight business, Air Cess, in [[Africa]] around the time of the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|collapse of the Soviet Union]], operating four [[Antonov An-8]] planes in Angola as it was the only country to allow the An-8 to be used in civilian freight at the time.<ref name="Bout">[http://www.victorbout.com/ Victor Bout's Personal Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329094156/http://www.victorbout.com/ |date=29 March 2010 }}. Victorbout.com.</ref> Reportedly, Bout's companies legally provided air freight services to the [[Government of France|French government]], the United Nations, and the [[United States]], including shipped [[flower]]s, frozen [[chicken]], [[United Nations peacekeeping|UN peacekeepers]], French soldiers, and African [[heads of state]].<ref name="Economist"/><ref name="NYT"/><ref name="merchant"/><ref name=de>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,721532,00.html Trapping the Lord of War, The Rise and Fall of Viktor Bout] Part 1. spiegel.de, 6 October 2010</ref><ref name="Mother"/><ref name="russian add1"/> Around this time, Bout earned the nickname "Sanctions Buster" due to being implicated of facilitating the violation of the United Nations [[arms embargo]]es in the western African countries of Angola, [[Liberia]], [[Sierra Leone]], and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]].<ref name="Amnesty">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090909233950/http://takeaction.amnestyusa.org/site/c.goJTI0OvElH/b.1297073/k.F283/Stop_Ruthless_Arms_Brokers_that_Fuel_Deadly_Conflicts.htm Stop Ruthless Arms Brokers that Fuel Deadly Conflicts] Amnesty International USA</ref>
Bout acknowledges having been to [[Afghanistan]] on numerous occasions during the 1990s, but has denied dealing with [[al-Qaeda]] or the [[Taliban]].<ref name="Four"/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/20/viktor-bout-profile "Viktor Bout: five passports, half a dozen languages and alleged friend to all sides"]. Guardian.</ref><ref name="CNN">[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0203/04/ltm.04.html Transcript of American Morning with Paula Zahn], 4 March 2002 (air date)</ref> Beginning in 1994, Bout made shipments for the pre-Taliban government of Afghanistan which later became the [[Northern Alliance]] and knew one of its commanders, [[Ahmad Shah Massoud]], with the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] described Bout-owned planes as transporters of [[small arms]] and [[ammunition]] into the country.<ref name="NYT"/><ref name=merchant-death-book/><ref name="CNN"/> In 1995, Bout was involved in negotiations to free [[Russia]]n hostages during the 1995 [[Airstan incident]].<ref name="Braun.Farah-60-65">{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Farah|first=Douglas|last2=Braun|first2=Stephen|title=Merchant of death: money, guns, planes, and the man who makes war possible|edition=2007|year=2007|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|isbn=978-0-470-04866-5 |pages=60–65}}</ref>
[[File:Centrafican IL-76T TL-ADH (6822783607).jpg|thumb|An [[Ilyushin Il-76|Il 76]] formerly used by Bout's Centrafrican Airlines]] [[File:Ilyushin Il-76 AN0197520.jpg|thumb|An Il 76 formerly used by Air Cess and Air Pass, both of which were owned by Bout]] In 2000, a United Nations report stated, "... [[Bulgaria|Bulgarian]] arms manufacturing companies had exported large quantities of different types of weapons between 1996 and 1998 on the basis of (forged<ref name="UNad"/>) [[end-user certificate]]s from [[Togo]]",<ref name="UNcopy"/> and that "... with only one exception, the company Air Cess, owned by Victor Bout, was the main transporter of these weapons from [[Burgas]] airport in Bulgaria".<ref name="UNcopy">[http://www.globalpolicy.org/component/content/article/202/41483.html Copy of the text of S/2000/1225] Final report of the Monitoring Mechanism on Angola Sanctions, UN Security Council, 21 December 2000</ref> This was the first time Bout was formally mentioned in connection with [[arms trafficking]], and the weapons may have been destined for use in the Angolan Civil War by [[UNITA]], the opposing faction of the MPLA which Bout had aided during his military service.<ref name="UNcopy"/><ref name=de2>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,721532-3,00.html Trapping the Lord of War, The Rise and Fall of Viktor Bout] Part 3: The Respected 'Mister Vik'. spiegel.de, 6 October 2010</ref> Another suspected arms dealer, Imad Kebir, is said to have employed Bout's aircraft during the mid-1990s to transport weapons to Africa from [[Eastern European]] states.<ref name="Dollars"/> The cargo supposedly had [[end-user certificate]]s from [[Zaire]], but the true end-user was UNITA in neighboring Angola.<ref name="Dollars"/> From 1993, UNITA was covered under [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 864|Resolution 864]], a United Nations Security Council embargo prohibiting the importation of arms to Angola.<ref name="UN2">[http://daccessdds.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N93/502/71/PDF/N9350271.pdf?OpenElement UN Security Council Resolution 864]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, PDF. 1993</ref>
In [[Liberia]], Bout was suspected of supplying [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]] with arms for use in the [[First Liberian Civil War]], with eyewitnesses claiming the two of conducting personal meetings.<ref>"Merchant of death: money, guns, planes, and the man who makes war possible". [[Douglas Farah]], Stephen Braun. p. 164</ref>
In 1993, Bout began collaborating with [[Syria]]n-born Richard Chichakli, and in 1995 the [[Sharjah International Airport]] in the [[United Arab Emirates]] hired Chichakli to be the commercial manager of its new [[free-trade zone]].<ref name=chic>Merchant of Death: Money, Guns, Planes, and the Man Who Makes War Possible (2007), pp. 53–56</ref> Bout began using the UAE's free trade zone and Chichakli was, at one time, called Bout's "financial manager" by the United States.<ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f28cf0f4-ebc6-11dc-9493-0000779fd2ac.html "Viktor Bout – elusive entrepreneur"]. ''Financial Times''. 6 March 2008</ref>
===2000s=== After the [[2001 invasion of Afghanistan]], Bout appeared in [[Moscow]] and stated that while his aircraft made regular flights to the country, and continued to deny any contact with al-Qaeda or the Taliban—instead supplying the rebel Northern Alliance.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/01/world/a-nation-challenged-a-suspect-russian-goes-on-the-air-to-deny-al-qaeda-ties.html |title=A Nation Challenged: A Suspect; Russian Goes on the Air To Deny Al Qaeda Ties |date=1 March 2002 |work=The New York Times |first=Michael|last=Wines}}</ref> He may have sold planes to the Taliban, however.<ref name=latimes>[http://articles.latimes.com/2002/may/19/news/ad-bout On the Trail of a Man Behind Taliban's Air Fleet]. The Los Angeles Times. 19 May 2002</ref> Soon after the beginning of the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|2001–2014 war in Afghanistan]], al-Qaeda is said to have moved [[gold]] and [[cash]] out of the country, with reports stating that some of the planes used to do this were linked to Bout.<ref name="Dollars">[http://www.globalwitness.org/media_library_get.php/171/1243947972/Few%20Dollars%20More%200-50.pdf For A Few Dollars More]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Global Witness, PDF. April 2003</ref> In July 2003, ''[[The New York Times]]'' interviewed Bout, who stated that "I woke up after [[September 11 attacks|Sept. 11]] and found I was second only to [[Osama bin Laden|Osama]]."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/17/magazine/17BOUT.html |title=Arms and the Man |date=7 August 2003 |work=The New York Times}}</ref>
Bout is suspected of supplying weapons to numerous armed groups in Africa in the 2000s, particularly in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] during the [[Second Congo War]], and may have employed some 300 people and operated 40 to 60 aircraft.<ref name="ethz">{{cite web|url=http://www.isn.ethz.ch/isn/Current-Affairs/Security-Watch/Detail/?id=88499&lng=en|title=The deadly convenience of Victor Bout|date=24 June 2008|publisher=ETH Zurich}}</ref> Bout's network allegedly delivered [[surface-to-air missile]]s to [[Kenya]] to be used to attack an [[Israel]]i airliner during takeoff in 2002.<ref>[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-14559750_ITM Moi Son's Link to Arms Dealer in UN Ban]. Africa News''. 23 November 2004.</ref>
Bout was also reportedly seen meeting with [[Hezbollah]] officials in [[Lebanon]] during the run-up to the [[Hezbollah#2006 Lebanon War|2006 Lebanon War]], while some sources claim he was actually in Russia when the meeting took place.<ref name=de3/> Records found in [[Libyan]] leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]]'s former intelligence headquarters in [[Tripoli]] shortly after the [[Libyan Civil War (2011)|overthrow]] of the [[History of Libya under Muammar Gaddafi|Gaddafi government]] in 2011 indicated that in late September 2003, [[MI6|British intelligence]] officials told then-Libyan intelligence chief [[Moussa Koussa|Musa Kusa]] that Bout had a "considerable commercial presence in Libya" and aimed to expand his interests there.<ref name="Libya">[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/khadafy-records-tie-russian-arms-dealer-libya-u-s-experts-hunt-anti-aircraft-missiles-article-1.972724 "Khadafy records tie Russian arms dealer to Libya, U.S. experts hunt for anti-aircraft missiles"] [[Associated Press]], 5 November 2011.</ref>
==Investigation== Bout's strategy of constantly moving location, owning numerous companies, and frequently re-registering aircraft made it hard for authorities to make a case against him, and has never been charged for the alleged African arms deals to which he owes his notoriety.<ref name="Economist"/><ref name="UNcopy"/><ref name="BBC 4">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7282576.stm Arms suspect faces charges in US] BBC, Friday, 7 March 2008, 13:36 GMT</ref> During Bout's reported operations, he is believed to have lived in various countries, including [[Belgium]], Lebanon, [[Rwanda]], Russia, South Africa, Syria, and the United Arab Emirates.<ref name="ethz"/><ref name="russian add1">http://www.isn.ethz.ch/isn/Current-Affairs/Security-Watch/Detail/?id=88500&lng=en ETH Zurich. 24 June 2008.</ref><ref name=de3>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,721532-4,00.html Trapping the Lord of War, The Rise and Fall of Viktor Bout] Part 4: Hired to Supply U.S. Forces in Iraq. spiegel.de, 6 October 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.publicintegrity.org/bow/report.aspx?aid=157|title=The Merchant of Death|author=André Verlöy}}</ref><ref name=mensjournal>{{cite web|url=http://www.mensjournal.com/viktor-bout/2|title=Taking Down Arms Dealer Viktor Bout|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325101613/http://www.mensjournal.com/viktor-bout/2|archivedate=25 March 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2000, Bout was charged in the [[Central African Republic]] with forging documents and was convicted ''[[in absentia]]'', but the charges were later dropped.<ref name="christsci">[http://features.csmonitor.com/globalnews/2009/10/22/who-is-viktor-bout "Who is Victor Bout?"] ''Global News Blog'' (''The Christian Science Monitor'') by Elizabeth Ryan, 22 October 2009</ref>
Belgian authorities requested that [[Interpol]] issue a [[INTERPOL notice|notice]] for Bout on charges of [[money laundering]], and in 2002 an [[Interpol notice|Interpol red notice]] on Bout was issued.<ref name="Mother">[https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2007/09/meet-viktor-bout-real-life-lord-war "Meet Viktor Bout, the Real-Life 'Lord of War'"] ''Mother Jones'', 13 September 2007</ref> Bout's website states that because he failed to appear in court a Belgian warrant (not the Interpol notice) for his arrest was issued but later cancelled.<ref name="Bout FAQ"/> The site has a document in Dutch to support the claim that the Belgian case against him was dismissed due to his lack of a fixed residence and because the case could not be prosecuted in a timely fashion.<ref name="Dutch doc">[http://www.victorbout.com/Documents/VB_Belgian_Court.pdf A Legal Document in Dutch] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306185316/http://www.victorbout.com/Documents/VB_Belgian_Court.pdf |date=6 March 2009 }} Victor Bout's Personal Website</ref>
===Executive Order 13348=== Bout's U.S. assets were among those frozen in July 2004 under [[s:Executive Order 13348|Executive Order 13348]], which describes him as a "businessman, dealer and transporter of weapons and [[mineral]]s" and cites his close association with Charles Taylor.<ref name="Bush Order">[http://www.victorbout.com/Documents/Exec%20Order%2013348.pdf United States Executive Order 13348] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306185310/http://www.victorbout.com/Documents/Exec%20Order%2013348.pdf |date=6 March 2009 }} Blocking Property of Certain Persons and Prohibiting the Importation of Certain Goods from Liberia, 27 July 2004</ref>
===Arrest=== On 6 March, 2008, Bout was arrested in [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] by the [[Royal Thai Police]] based on an Interpol red notice requested by the United States based on conspiracy to provide material support or resources to a designated foreign terrorist organization.<ref name="Interpol1">[http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20080314221834/http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2008/PR200810.asp INTERPOL praises international co-operation behind arrest of suspected international arms dealer by Thai Police], Media release, [[INTERPOL]], 7 March 2008. Retrieved 18 April 2015</ref> The culmination of a [[sting operation]] set up by [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] agents,<ref name="Observer">[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/09/armstrade.internationalcrime "Revealed: trap that lured the merchant of death"] ''The Observer'', Sunday, 9 March 2008</ref> Allegedly, Bout offered to supply weapons to people he thought were representatives of the [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia]] (FARC) rebels.<ref name="Economist"/><ref name="Observer"/> After months of delay, the Criminal Court in Bangkok began an extradition hearing for Bout on 22 September 2008.<ref name="BBC 3">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7628863.stm "Russian 'arms dealer' trial opens"], BBC, Monday, 22 September 2008</ref> In February 2009, members of the [[United States Congress]] signed a letter to Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] and Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] expressing their wish that the Bout extradition "remain a top priority".<ref name="Letter to Clinton">[http://www.victorbout.com/Documents/Bout_Congress_ltr_2009.pdf A letter to Secretary of State Mrs. Clinton regarding Bout extradition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101011215920/http://www.victorbout.com/Documents/Bout_Congress_ltr_2009.pdf |date=11 October 2010 }}. PDF, Victor Bout's personal website</ref>
===Extradition=== On 11 August 2009, the Bangkok Criminal Court ruled in his favor, denying the United States' request for extradition and citing the political, not criminal, nature of the case.<ref name=denial>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8194824.stm|title=Thailand rejects Bout extradition|date=11 August 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=11 August 2009}}</ref> The United States appealed that ruling, and on 20 August 2010, a higher court in Thailand ruled that Bout could, in fact, be extradited to the United States.<ref name="'Merchant of Death' to be Extradited">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704476104575440553348497506 |title=Thailand Says It Will Extradite Russia's 'Merchant of Death' |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=21 August 2010 |first=James|last=Hookway}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/20/AR2010082000452.html |title=Suspected Russian arms dealer Bout to be extradited to U.S., Thai court rules |newspaper=Washington Post |date=20 August 2010 |first=John|last=Pomfret}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/russia-and-us-go-to-war-over-merchant-of-death-2058066.html |title=Russia and US go to war over 'Merchant of Death': Fury in Moscow after Washington wins battle to put suspected arms dealer Viktor Bout on trial |newspaper=Independent |date=21 August 2010 |location=London}}</ref>
[[File:Viktor Bout Extradited to US.jpg|350px|thumb|Viktor Bout in the custody of [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]] agents on 16 November 2010 after being extradited to the United States]]
On 16 November 2010, Bout was [[extradited]] from Thailand to the United States amid protests by the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]], who deemed it illegal.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/17/world/asia/17thai.html |title=Russian Arrives in U.S. to Face Arms Charges |date=16 November 2009 |work=New York Times |accessdate=16 November 2010 |first=Seth |last=Mydans}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/17/world/asia/17thai.html |title=Russian Arrives in U.S. to Face Arms Charges |date=16 November 2009 |work=New York Times |accessdate=16 November 2010 |first=Seth |last=Mydans}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11763221 |title=Extradition of 'arms dealer' Viktor Bout goes ahead |date=16 November 2010 |work=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/11/16/thailand.extradition/?hpt=Sbin |title=Thailand extradites accused international arms dealer |date=16 November 2010 |work=CNN}}</ref>
===Russian protests=== Russia called the Thai court decision in 2010 politically motivated.<ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/world/192280/pm-defends-bout-court-decision "PM defends Bout court decision – Russia summons Thai ambassador"]</ref><ref>[http://ibnlive.in.com/generalnewsfeed/news/russia-condemns-thai-decision-on-bouts-extradition/248773.html "Russia condemns Thai decision on Bout''s extradition"]. Ibnlive.in.com (20 August 2010).</ref> Its [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign Ministry]] took steps to prevent Bout being extradited to the U.S.;<ref name=de/> Russia's Foreign Minister [[Sergei Lavrov]] suggested that Bout was innocent.<ref name=de/>
On 18 November 2010, shortly after Bout's extradition to the United States, [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev|Medvedev]]'s [[Presidential Administration of Russia|aide]] Sergei Eduardovich Prikhodko said that Russia had "nothing to hide" in Bout's criminal case stating, "it is in our interest that the investigation ... be brought to completion, and [Bout] should answer all the questions the American justice system has."<ref name="ReutPrikh">{{Cite news |first=Denis|last=Dyomkin |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6AH2SC20101118 |agency=Reuters |title=Russia says 'nothing to hide' in arms suspect case |date=18 November 2010 |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="NEWSruPrikh">{{cite news |url=http://newsru.com/russia/18nov2010/viktor.html |publisher=[[NEWSru]] |date=18 November 2010 |accessdate=29 November 2010 |script-title=ru:Россия окончательно "сдала" Виктора Бута американцам: хочет полного следствия по всем обвинениям |trans-title=Russia Has Definitively "Surrendered" Viktor Bout to the Americans and Wants Full Investigation of Charges |language=Russian}}</ref> On 18 January 2013, Russian government officials announced that "judges, investigators, justice ministry officials and special services agents who were involved in Russian citizens Viktor Bout's and Konstantin Yaroshenko's legal prosecution and sentencing to long terms of imprisonment" would be added to a list of U.S. officials who will be denied Russian entry visas in response for the U.S. "[[Magnitsky Act]]", under which certain Russian officials are ineligible to enter the U.S.<ref name="Gitmo">{{Cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-russian-guantanamo-list-20130118,0,1877573.story |title=Russians draft 'Guantanamo list' to sanction U.S. officials |first=Sergei L.|last=Loiko |date=18 January 2013 |publisher=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
It is thought that Bout was of help to Russia's [[Intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]],<ref name="extradition"/> and he is alleged to have connections to ranking Russian officials, including former deputy prime minister [[Igor Sechin]].<ref name="NWSech">{{Cite news|last=Matthews|first=Owen |newspaper=[[Newsweek]]|date=2 September 2010|accessdate=30 November 2010|title =What Is the Kremlin Hiding?|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2010/09/02/viktor-bout-s-secrets-frighten-the-kremlin.html}}</ref> The language institute Bout attended has been linked to the [[Main Intelligence Directorate|GRU]], and Bout allegedly served alongside the GRU-affiliated Sechin in [[Mozambique]] in the 1980s, although both men deny this allegation.<ref name="ethz"/><ref name=de/><ref name=merchant-death-book>{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Farah|first=Douglas|last2=Braun|first2=Stephen |title=Merchant of death: money, guns, planes, and the man who makes war possible |edition=2007 |year=2007 |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |isbn=978-0-470-04866-5}} 308 pages</ref><ref name=mensjournal/><ref name=forbes>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/08/15/victor-bout-kremlin-opinions-contributors-dmitry-sidorov.html |title=Nothing To Worry A Bout? |work=Forbes |date=15 August 2008 |quote=According to a report by Stratfor, an American analytic outfit, Bout served with Igor Sechin in Mozambique in the 1980s. |first=Dmitry |last=Sidorov}}</ref> According to a 2002 United Nations report, Bout's father-in-law Zuiguin "at one point held a high position in the [[KGB]], perhaps even as high as a deputy chairman".<ref name="ethz"/>
==Prosecution and conviction in the United States== The day after his Bangkok arrest, the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] charged Bout with conspiracy to provide material support or resources to a [[Office of Foreign Assets Control|designated]] foreign terrorist organization,<ref name="DOJ">[http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/2008/March/nsd_03062008.html "International Arms Dealer Charged in U.S. with Conspiracy to Provide Surface-to-Air Missiles and other Weapons to a Foreign Terrorist Organization"]. United States Department of Justice.</ref> conspiring to kill Americans, conspiring to kill American officers or employees, and conspiring to acquire and use an anti-aircraft missile.<ref name="BBC 3"/> Additional charges against him were filed in February 2010.<ref name=news>[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/02/17/arms.dealer.charge/index.html "US files new charges against arms dealer Viktor Bout"]. CNN.com, 17 February 2010.</ref> These included illegal purchase of aircraft, [[wire fraud]], and [[money laundering]].<ref name=lead1>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100723020721/http://www.justice.gov/usao/nys/pressreleases/February10/boutviktoretals1indictmentpr.pdf "U.S. Announces New Indictment Against International Arms Dealer Viktor Bout and American Co-Conspirator for Money Laundering, Wire Fraud, and Conspiracy"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723020721/http://www.justice.gov/usao/nys/pressreleases/February10/boutviktoretals1indictmentpr.pdf |date=23 July 2010 }}. PDF, U.S. Indictment released 17 February 2010.</ref>
Bout was convicted by a jury at a court in [[Manhattan]] on 2 November 2011.<ref name="AP-11-2-2011" /> On 5 April 2012, he was sentenced to 25 years in prison, the minimum sentence for conspiring to sell weapons to a U.S.-designated foreign terrorist group.<ref name=aljazeera_sentencing/><ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/Russian-Arms-Trafficker-Viktor-Bout-Gets-25-Years-in-US-Prison-146371955.html "Russian Arms Trafficker Viktor Bout Gets 25 Years in US Prison"]. Voice of America, 5 April 2012.</ref> District Judge [[Shira Scheindlin]] ruled that the minimum sentence was appropriate because "there was no evidence that Bout would have committed the crimes for which he was convicted had it not been for the [[sting operation]]".<ref name=aljazeera_sentencing/> Russia's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] issued a statement denouncing Bout's sentence as "a political order".<ref name=aljazeera_sentencing/> During the trial, Bout's lawyers also implied that he was a [[political prisoner]].<ref name=aljazeera_sentencing>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2012/04/20124522433245829.html |title=Russian arms dealer gets 25 years in prison |work=Al Jazeera |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012}}</ref> Bout's wife Alla said shortly afterwards that the judge conducted the trial in a proper way.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_04_09/71131268 |publisher=Voice of Russia (The) |date=9 April 2012 |accessdate=9 April 2012 |title=Alla Bout: husband's trial conducted 'properly' |author=Jessica Jordan & Liudmila Chernova |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120411025222/http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_04_09/71131268/ |archivedate=11 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Bout himself pointed out that if the same standards were applied to everyone, all American [[gun shop]] owners "who are sending arms and ending up killing Americans" would be in prison.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://rt.com/politics/viktor-bout-trial-weapon-233/ |title=Bout: I'm a hunted deer, US wants my head on their trophy-wall |work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]] |date=4 April 2012}}</ref>
In June 2013, a co-conspirator of Bout's, Richard Ammar Chichakli, was extradited to [[New York (state)|New York]] state on charges that he conspired to buy aircraft in violation of economic sanctions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Associate of arms dealer Viktor Bout extradited to New York |author=Chris Francescani |publisher=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/25/us-arms-bout-chichakli-idUSBRE94O00220130525 |date=24 May 2013}}</ref>
In September 2013, the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York upheld Bout's conviction after rejecting his contention that he had been the victim of a vindictive prosecution and that there was no legitimate [[law enforcement]] reason to prosecute him.<ref>{{cite web |title=Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout's U.S. conviction upheld |author=Chris Francescani |publisher=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/27/us-usa-crime-bout-idUSBRE98Q0PG20130927 |date=27 September 2013}}</ref>
As of 2014, former US Attorney General [[John Ashcroft]] is representing Bout in overturning his conviction via a new trial.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stempel|first1=Jonathan|title=Arms dealer Bout seeks new trial, hires Ashcroft law firm|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-crime-bout/arms-dealer-bout-seeks-new-trial-hires-ashcroft-law-firm-idUSKCN0JJ20H20141205}}</ref>
==Popular culture== The 2005 film ''[[Lord of War]]'' is purportedly based on allegations about Bout's personal history and black-market activities.<ref name="Economist">[http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12795502 "Flying Anything to Anybody"], ''The Economist'', 18 December 2008</ref><ref name=de/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7281297.stm "Thailand holds 'top arms dealer'"], BBC, Thursday, 6 March 2008 * [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/21/world/asia/21thai.html "Arms Suspect Vows to Win Case in U.S. After Extradition Order"] nytimes.com, 21 August 2010 * [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/16/movies/16lord.html "Guns Are Evil. Everybody Should Have One"]. ''The New York Times'', 16 September 2005</ref>
A documentary about Bout, ''[[The Notorious Mr. Bout]]'', from [[Market Road Films]] and directed by [[Tony Gerber]] and [[Maxim Pozdorovkin]], received its premiere at the 2014 [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/sundance-2014-world-cinema-documentary-competition | title=Sundance 2014: World Cinema Documentary Competition | publisher=indiewire.com | work=Indiewire | date=10 January 2014 | accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref>
In 2007, Stephen Braun and [[Douglas Farah]] published a book about Bout: ''Merchant of Death: Money, Guns, Planes, and the Man Who Makes War Possible''.<ref name=merchant-death-book/>
